newsitem.title: BELARUS: Belarus names economy minister, cheering analysts.
newsitem.headline: Belarus names economy minister, cheering analysts.

text.p: Belarussian President Alexander Lukashenko has named a new economy minister, cheering analysts who welcomed the move as a step in the right direction in the credit-starved former Soviet republic.
Lukashenko's press office said on Wednesday that Vladimir Shimov, who had been a deputy economy minister since August 1995, would fill the post following a decree signed on Tuesday.

Analysts based in the capital of the republic sandwiched between Russia and Poland welcomed Shimov's promotion. "I personally am very optimistic about the appointment," one Minsk-based economist told Reuters.
"Shimov is reputed to be a very highly qualified professional and more market-oriented and aware of market needs than some," said a Western analyst who asked not to be named.

Lukashenko has taken a go-slow approach to reforming his republic of 10 million after years of Soviet stagnation, freezing privatisation and keeping a tight rein on banks and on the national rouble currency.
The World Bank halted credit in May, pending faster reforms. In March, the International Monetary Fund froze most of a $300 million standby credit agreed last year.
"Shimov's appointment will certainly not do any harm, but it remains to be seen how forceful he can be in pushing any reforms through," the Western analyst said.
Shimov's predecessor, Georgy Badei, quit in July after being accused at a Security Council meeting of ruining the economy.
An official close to him said Lukashenko's administration had "repeatedly ignored the minister's proposals intended to speed up reforms".
The economist said Shimov had worked in close contact with the World Bank on an economic programme to 2000 which Lukashenko rejected and replaced with his own version.
"The programme worked on by the economic ministry, including Shimov, with the World Bank is notable for its market orientation," the economist said.
"Unfortunately that programme did not become the basis of the president's one, though thanks to Shimov many proposals which had astonished Western experts were removed," he added.
Shimov had succeeded in particular in removing plans to impose tight controls on prices and on monetary policy and to increase emissions significantly, he added.
Shimov was deputy head of an academic economic institute in Minsk before joining the ministry last year.
Of Bulgarian parentage, he is a doctor of economic sciences and until 1976 he worked at "Gosplan", a committee which drew up plans for the economy before the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991.
